text:
7 yo: You said they'd be here at 1. It's 1:02.
Me: So? 
7 yo:  So you were wrong.
Me: I said they'd be here *around* 1. If they show up at 1:05, would that mean they got here around 1? 
7 yo: Yes.
Me, triumphantly: So, am I wrong?
<pause>
7 yo, triumphantly: We don't know yet.

text: @Cantide1 @QuantaMagazine Here the triangle is equilateral because the overlapping circles pass through each others' centers. A different configuration would produce a different overlap. And if the radii are not congruent, you get a lens, which is very tricky!

text: Finding tangent parabolas is easy! Just find the coefficients of ax¬≤ + bx + c that yield the desired values. But it's also a great opportunity to appreciate the alternate formulation of the polynomial as c + b(x-k) + a(x-k)¬≤, where x=k is the center of the approximation.

text: @DMarfise88 These are extensions of tangent lines: Tangent lines match f(x) at value and 1st derivative; Tangent parabolas match f(x) at value, 1st derivative, and 2nd derivative.
bbox_coords: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
name: Patrick Honner
description: Math teacher. Instructional Coach. Writer. National STEM Ambassador. Presidential Award winner. @MathforAmerica MT. @QuantaMagazine columnist. @NYTimesLearning

text: The tangent parabola extends the concept of the tangent line: The tangent line matches f(x) in value and 1st derivative; the tangent parabola matches f(x) in value, 1st derivative, and 2nd derivative. This is how I introduce Taylor polynomials.
bbox_coords: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA

text: @shskaercher In general this isn't a compelling argument. The triangle area formula is just the parallelogram area formula. Ratios are just fractions. Integrals are just sums. Everything is just everything else. But we study different representations because of what they allow us to do.
bbox_coords: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
name: Patrick Honner
description: Math teacher. Instructional Coach. Writer. National STEM Ambassador. Presidential Award winner. @MathforAmerica MT. @QuantaMagazine columnist. @NYTimesLearning

text: @shskaercher I've heard people say things like "Don't teach the distance formula; it's just the Pythagorean Theorem." Of course it is! It's a specific application of the Pythagorean Theorem, and should be taught as such. But it offers something different than the Pythagorean Theorem.

text: If you seeded a knockout tournament with 2^n teams and the  better seed always won, in round m the sum of the seeds facing each other would always be 2^(n-m+1)+1. This gives you a way to measure the "upsettedness" of a knockout tournament.

text: A number is perfect if it is a positive integer, n, whose divisors add up to exactly twice the number itself, 2n. Could an odd perfect number exist? ‚ÄúIt is indeed a problem for the ages, [and] perhaps it will remain so,‚Äù said math professor John Voight. https://t.co/3LPMaprRZK

text: @mrsvibbermath @EulersNephew @LetsLearnCalc @RamsayNancy @Calculord @elizabethmunch @sara_ann_jensen Think about the approximation by line segments. A segment with endpoints (x,f(x)) and (x+h, f(x+h)) is mapped to a segment with endpoints (x,f(0.25x+1)) and (x+h, f(0.25(x+h)+1). I think the difference in these lengths depends on f and literally could be anything.

text: @mrsvibbermath @EulersNephew @LetsLearnCalc @RamsayNancy @Calculord @elizabethmunch @sara_ann_jensen I don't think this can be answered in general. The effect of the transformation on f can't be captured in a simple enough way to relate back to the original arclength calculation. The failure of the straightforward u-sub demonstrates this I think.

text: @CardColm I think lots of "real math" involves understanding what the definitions of mathematical objects are, what those definitions entail, and the difference between the two.
bbox_coords: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
name: Patrick Honner
description: Math teacher. Instructional Coach. Writer. National STEM Ambassador. Presidential Award winner. @MathforAmerica MT. @QuantaMagazine columnist. @NYTimesLearning

text: @RobJLow No. The problem is the form of their argument. Their justification should be "If B then A", but the statement "A parallelogram has two pair of opposite, congruent sides is "If A then B". (A = quad is parallelogram, B = quad has two pair of opposite, congruent sides).
bbox_coords: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
name: Patrick Honner
description: Math teacher. Instructional Coach. Writer. National STEM Ambassador. Presidential Award winner. @MathforAmerica MT. @QuantaMagazine columnist. @NYTimesLearning

text: @DavidKButlerUoA @realShannaMae Yes! There are many biconditional theorems which essentially function as alternative definitions of parallelograms. Which is why it's so tricky.
bbox_coords: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
name: Patrick Honner
description: Math teacher. Instructional Coach. Writer. National STEM Ambassador. Presidential Award winner. @MathforAmerica MT. @QuantaMagazine columnist. @NYTimesLearning

text: @DavidKButlerUoA @realShannaMae No. The issue is that when trying to prove a quadrilateral is a parallelogram, students are arguing that it's a parallelogram because it has some property that a parallelogram has, not that it has some property that parallelograms and *only* parallelograms have.
bbox_coords: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
name: Patrick Honner
description: Math teacher. Instructional Coach. Writer. National STEM Ambassador. Presidential Award winner. @MathforAmerica MT. @QuantaMagazine columnist. @NYTimesLearning

text: @PaulaKrieg Seriously.
bbox_coords: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
name: Patrick Honner
description: Math teacher. Instructional Coach. Writer. National STEM Ambassador. Presidential Award winner. @MathforAmerica MT. @QuantaMagazine columnist. @NYTimesLearning

text: @DavidKButlerUoA @Trianglemancsd @realShannaMae This is one of the reasons I find teaching symbolic logic so useful in this course, as you and I have discussed before. (For example, the idea that biconditionals function as definitions.)  I had to pare down that unit this year and I think this is a consequence.
bbox_coords: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
name: Patrick Honner
description: Math teacher. Instructional Coach. Writer. National STEM Ambassador. Presidential Award winner. @MathforAmerica MT. @QuantaMagazine columnist. @NYTimesLearning

text: @realShannaMae Which is what the students often need.
bbox_coords: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
name: Patrick Honner
description: Math teacher. Instructional Coach. Writer. National STEM Ambassador. Presidential Award winner. @MathforAmerica MT. @QuantaMagazine columnist. @NYTimesLearning

text: @realShannaMae "A parallelogram has two pairs of opposite, congruent sides" is equivalent to "If a quad is a parallelogram, then it has two pairs of opposite, congruent sides". This articulates a consequence of being a parallelogram, not a reason to conclude something *is* a parallelogram.
bbox_coords: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
name: Patrick Honner
description: Math teacher. Instructional Coach. Writer. National STEM Ambassador. Presidential Award winner. @MathforAmerica MT. @QuantaMagazine columnist. @NYTimesLearning

text: Note to self:  Do a better job next year making sure students know that "A parallelogram has two pairs of opposite, congruent sides" does not mean "If a quadrilateral has two pairs of opposite, congruent sides, then it is a parallelogram".
bbox_coords: NA NA NA NA NA NA NA NA
name: Patrick Honner
description: Math teacher. Instructional Coach. Writer. National STEM Ambassador. Presidential Award winner. @MathforAmerica MT. @QuantaMagazine columnist. @NYTimesLearning

text: My family and I have been enjoying The Mind game. Make a deck of cards, numbered 1 to 100. First round---deal out one card to each person. The goal is cooperative: play them in order from least to greatest. Second round---two cards per person, and so on. What fun!

With the net drawn the right way, it‚Äôs so obvious!

text: @Atrix256 It's very much like optimal transport! An example of chord inversion is playing a C chord as E - G - C instead of C - E - G. Say you're playing an F chord as F-A-C: you can move to a C chord by moving two fingers one key each (E to F and A to G), instead of moving your whole hand

text:
@mrdardy @mikeandallie @bowenkerins The function isn't differentiable at any integer since the slope of the tangent lines on one side are all 0 and on the other aside approach infinity. The (two-sided) limit of the difference quotient doesn't exist. (The mantra 
"differentiability implies continuity" applies here.)

text:
@mikeandallie Big ideas for me:
1) Graphing; visualization; lines/planes in 3D
2) Extending notions of function (beyond y=f(x)) and derivative (beyond dy/dx)
3) Gradient and directional derivative
4) Extending Riemann sums (multi; vector)
5) Parameterization / change of coordinates
